instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight Issue
threads.message:
Hello guys!

I have a MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight issue. Customer brought it in because it would not turn on after it went black randomly while browsing.

Plugged in charger and it was giving 20v @ 0 amps. I found a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Fixed it by replacing <CHIP>U7430</CHIP>. No more short, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13 volts, MacBook now turns on, makes charge connection sound, but no backlight (I can see faint Apple logo and it would boot / go to recovery assistant).

There is no sign of liquid.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13 volts (12.3 - 12.5 volts if battery is connected)
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> = 55 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight Issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight Issue
threads.message:
55V on backlight means open LED strips connection.
So LCD assembly is first suspect...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight Issue
threads.message:
Luckily I had another display to test, it definitely is the LCD assembly. However, I am unsure if the customer will be willing to bring to Apple for the backlight service program. He took it there initially and now it is obvious that it was worked on.

Anyone have any success in repairing the daughter board for the LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight Issue
threads.message:
I compared screen assembly readings and here are my findings. I noticed pin 33 varies a lot on the bad assembly - <SIGNAL>MIPI_DATA_CONN_P</SIGNAL>, but other than that everything else seem to check out. I don't think this pin has anything to do with backlight, so it might just be done for.
[ATTACH type="full" alt="1591718230754.png"]59271[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight Issue
threads.message: Just clean your work so that it's not completely obvious that the board has been worked on and bring it to Apple, best course of actions. If it's flexgate they must fix their mistake. If it's not flexgate, ehâ€¦ still an opportunity not to pay $400 for a replacement LCD assembly.
